newsitem.title: USA: Russia, U.S. discuss jewels in Washington.
newsitem.headline: Russia, U.S. discuss jewels in Washington.

text.p: Russian and U.S. negotiators made progress in talks on Thursday to determine if a priceless collection of Romanov jewels and art objects can continue a planned U.S. tour or must go back to Moscow.

Russia is demanding that the collection, which includes some of the world's largest gems, should be returned despite written agreements with an American organiser for a year-long tour of U.S. museums.

Russian Deputy Culture Minister Mikhail Shvydkoy met at the Russian Embassy with James Symington, a former congressman and U.S. protocol chief who is head of the American-Russian Cooperation Foundation, which mounted the exhibition by borrowing over $400,000.
Each side disputes the other's accounting for the costs and expenses of the exhibit.
In a joint statement issued late on Thursday, the two sides said "considerable progress" had been made.
"We look forward to the continuation of productive negotiations and hope we are able to move forward and bring the matter to a positive conclusion as soon as possible," the statement said.
Vitaly Ignatenko, Itar-Tass news agency's general director, flew in on Wednesday to help in the talks. Until last month, he was a deputy prime minister responsible for the media.
In Moscow, officials were adamant that the collection should be returned if there is no settlement of a dispute that involves both money and control over the exhibition.

"If an agreement is not reached between the two sides to continue the exhibition, we will have to act fairly quickly and sharply and bring the items back to Russia," Deputy Culture Minister Pavel Khoroshilov told Reuters.
He said U.S. organisers failed to exchange a series of documents related to the exhibition, including financial matters.

"The Russian Embassy says numerous efforts to get the Americans to the negotiating table have failed," Khoroshilov said. "The Ministry of Culture is now worried about a situation which could to a certain extent jeopordize the security of these items."
In a 10-week exhibition at Washington's Corcoran Gallery of Art, over 80,000 people paid $9 each to view the collection.
The exhibition was timed to commemorate the U.S. visit 125 years ago of Grand Duke Alexis. The Romanovs ruled Russia for 300 years, ending in the 1917 Communist revolution.

Last Wednesday, Russian Embassy cars blocked a moving van from taking the art works to Houston, the next stop on its tour, and the Corcoran locked away the jewels in a vault until the dispute is settled.
The two sides agreed on Tuesday to move the van to the Russian Embassy grounds for security reasons and as a sign of goodwill.
